page.title: 13THE WARREN
page.content: The Warren is the area of coastland to the east of Folkestone Harbour and Copt Point.Chalk cliffs lie above blue gault clay (highly fossiliferous). The Warren has been formed by rotational landslipping of the chalk upon the gault clay,caused by marine erosion and massive slumping of the foot of the gault.Landslides still occasionally occur.Along the coast concrete breakwaters and sea walls have been built as sea defences. At Lydden Spout a freshwater spring appears on the foreshore and numerous adits drain the chalk. The Warren is designated a site of 'special scientific interest'.It has areas of grassland with many rare orchids and woodland where the largest colony of Hart's Tongue Fern flourishes.Many migrant birds, especially Nightingales shelter here.
